reviewText:
The Lost and Damned
This episode focuses on motorcycles, as you would expect from a game that revolves around a biker gang. If GTA4 wasn't gritty enough for you, this one's even grittier. Storywise, it's about the same level of grittiness as GTA4, if not more, If you like riding bikes, you'll like this episode; Johnny Klebitz has mastered the delicate art of not flying off his bike when clipping a lamp post at 20 miles an hour. Though he's not as good of a driver as Niko, and you'll definitely notice that if and when you get behind the wheel. There's more content in general, including an exclusive set of weapons to play with, including an autopistol, a sawed-off shotgun, and a grenade launcher. You get all three of these pretty damn early in the game; the sawed-off is Johnny's starter weapon and he can fire it while riding! Worth playing if you want to follow a parallel, equally if not more gritty story to Niko's.

Lost MC! Lost MC!



The Ballad of Gay Tony
This episode takes a leap away from GTA4's usual brand of grittiness; it's more colorful, has lots of new fun guns to play with (P90 SMG, advanced sniper rifle, M249 light machine gun, AA-12 shotgun with explosive rounds...), parachutes, upgraded police units, and a whackier tone to compete with its new nemesis, Saints Row 2. This one focuses a bit more on helicopters, so this episode may be good practice for the awful PC controls for the helicopters. Or it may frustrate you a bit. Once you finish the story, you can go back and replay any mission you want. There's a score system for missions this time around, but who cares? I actually find this episode to be more fun than GTA4 just because of all the fun stuff it adds. There's nothing like screwing up everyone's commute in Star Junction with stickybombs and an explosive shotgun. What's that? The police are coming? Pfft. They ain't got ♥♥♥♥ on my APC.

You'll have a good time. And as always, mods only increase the fun.

Episodes from Liberty City puts you in the shoes of other people trying to make something of themselves in this world. Unlike Niko however, Luis and Johnny have been in this city for a long time; they know what's going on.

The moral of the story is, we all have a dream, but someone already owns that dream. Sometimes there's people with the exact same dream as you, they're also chasing it. And if you don't make friends with them, bad things are going to happen. In the end, no one achieves that dream, because we all killed each other; but in the end, that dream is given to those who deserve it. And a new chapter of the book begins....

As I write this, the release date for GTA V is fast approaching. Hard to believe it's been 5 years since GTA4 was released.

GTA: Episodes from Liberty City (EFLC) moves the base GTA4 game forward nicely. There's two smaller storylines, each about 12-16 hours of gameplay. Both stories are interwoven with the main GTA4 storyline. Niko Bellic and other characters make appearances in these games, and certain loose ends are tied up in these episodes.

The stories are strong, the supporting characters are interesting, and the protagonists are fun to play. Luis Lopez, the main character in The Ballad of Gay Tony, is my new favorite GTA protagonist - even better than Vice City's Tommy Vercetti. These two smaller games are much more interesting to me than Niko Bellic's story.

EFLC delivers some technical fixes and gameplay improvements to the base game.  Most notably, we now have mid-mission checkpoints, so if you fail a mission, you can pick up part-way through. This really decreases the frustration level of the game. Less notably, but important to me: traffic is more realistic. And, motorcycles are easier to control.

The Ballad of Gay Tony is the standout episode. It brings back the over-the-top flavor of Vice City and San Andreas. This is pretty much GTA IV on steroids.
TLaD expands the base game a bit, especially by adding many new bikes.
TBoGT feels like a true evolution (something like Vice City compared to GTA III). There is a quite significant amount of new vehicles (which reappear in GTA V), fun weapons and other minor details, like base jumping. reviewText:
Grand Theft Auto: Episodes from Liberty City is a third-person open-world adventure shooter. Play either as Johnny Klebitz, the VP of The Lost biker club, or Luis Fernando Lopez, henchman of Gay Tony, as you strive through the criminal underworld of Liberty City.

Pros: This is two full campaigns for Grand Theft Auto IV but doesn't require the original game to run. These are characters that crossed Niko Bellic's path in the original campaign, but their stories happen in parallel to it, allowing you to see who they were, deal with their troubles on their end, giving you a chance to understand events that happened behind the curtains of crimes Niko was involved in. Both are full-fledged story lines of their own, with its own lot of unique characters you come across and gameplay elements. Your new friends brings new perks of their own, and new locations.

Cons: You don't have the same feeling of discovery in this game as it's the one as Grand Theft Auto IV, with some locations or stores no longer available. You have a lot less mini-games and side quests, and much if the character customization is gone. There is no major change to the city.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

It's more of the same, so it's all up to you. If you didn't enjoy Grand Theft Auto IV that much, there is no reason to buy this. However, if you did like GTA4 and wished you could play more campaign mode in Liberty City, these will deliver!

reviewText:
Episodes from Liberty City é um pacote com as duas expansões de GTA 4, inicialmente lançadas separadamente, sendo que podem ser jogadas mesmo sem possuir o jogo de base. Ambas trazem pequenas variações no mapa em relação ao original e algumas pequenas novidades.

O primeiro episódio, The Lost and Damned, diz respeito a uma gangue de motoqueiros que teve seu líder (Billy Grey) capturado pela polícia. Até que ele pudesse retornar, a gangue passou a ser comandada por Johnny Klebitz que guiou seus companheiros à prosperidade.

No entanto, anos se passaram e com o retorno de Billy, ele estava totalmente transformado de forma que sua liderança estava destruindo tudo que havia sido construído e pondo em risco seus membros. Esta situação faz com que alguns dos membros se revoltem.

Nesta expansão, o jogador controla Johnny, que por sinal se movimenta muito devagar, bem mais devagar que Nicko. Como há um maior foco em motocicletas, foram acrescentados alguns modelos novos e tornou-se praticamente impossível cair delas.

Uma coisa ruim é que as vozes dos motoqueiros não combinam com os personagens e nos faz ter dificuldade de saber quem é quem está falando, o que prejudica um pouco o entendimento dos diálogos.

Já o segundo episódio, The Ballad of Gay Tony, assumimos o papel de Luis Lopez, braço direito de Tony Prince, um viadinho dono das melhores boates em Liberty City. Luis é sócio de Tony e eles são apenas amigos, sendo que não há nenhuma outra relação entre eles.

Diferente dos outros personagens, Luis vive na vida boa, tem um bom apartamento e várias mulheres. O problema é que o negócio das boates já não está tão lucrativo como antes, e seu mentor Tony se meteu em algumas enrascadas tentando diversificar os investimentos.

The Ballad of Gay Tony tem as melhores músicas tocando nas rádios contando todos os GTA’s já lançados, pelo menos na minha opinião, além de missões frenéticas e um sistema de pontuação por missão que premia o jogador em realiza-las usando métodos específicos.

Há nas duas expansões algumas adições muito bem vindas, como um sistema de checkpoints nas missões em que, no caso de falha, o jogador não precisa repetir a missão desde o começo, mas sim do último checkpoint.

Também foram adicionados novos mini games, como queda de braço e competição de bebida, corridas com bastões e habilidade para dançar. Foi retirada (felizmente) a necessidade de ficar ligando para as pessoas para manter relacionamentos.

O interessante é que as tramas das expansões ocorrem paralelamente a do jogo principal, sendo que por várias vezes passamos pelo mesmo local onde ocorreu algum evento e podemos ver os personagens dos outros jogos realizando as ações que fizemos, quando estávamos jogando com eles.

Além disso, as histórias são interligadas, com várias referencias cruzadas, e há situações em que realizaremos missões  com a participação dos personagens dos outros jogos, o que nos ajuda a entender melhor qual o que ocorreu em cada evento.

Algo que já acontecia no GTA 4 original, mas agora é muito frequente é o recebimento de alguma ligação que faz iniciar uma missão qualquer... Isso é muito chato porque não há como não aceitar e você deverá fazer aquela missão compulsoriamente naquele momento, mesmo que tivesse em mente fazer outra coisa.

Não se pode deixar de mencionar que também foram herdados alguns bugs do título principal, mas pelo menos são bem menos numerosos, e não atrapalham tanto jogar como eram naquele, de forma que não há quase nada para reclamar do jogo.

No fim das contas, se você jogou GTA 4, é praticamente obrigatório que você jogue suas expansões também, pois são bastante sólidas e talvez até mais divertidas que o título principal. EXCELENTE (9/10).

Summary: Overall The Ballad of Gay Tony and The Lost and Damned are great standalones with slight improvements to the original GTA 4. Each one offers roughly 5-9 hours of gameplay and new elements such as parachuting, base jumping, mini-games, weapons, and vehicles. 4.5/5.

Packaged together, Episodes from Liberty City offer two standalone games that take on very different approaches to the original gameplay in GTA 4. Both offer their own single-player campaigns with roughly 5 hours of missions, mini-games, and a variety of new weapons and vehicles to spice up your experience. The stories, just like the original, are well-written and interweaves with Niko Bellic. Playing the original and then through the episodes will give a second perspective on who did what, where the diamonds came from, and so on. They aren't heavily dependent on knowing the original plot, but they can be better appreciated if you've played through it.

The Lost and Damned takes the perspective of Johnny Klebitz, the vice-president of The Lost Motorcycle Club (TLMC). As you would expect, you primarily travel by motorcycle and much of the storyline is around the MC and their conflict with the police, rival gangs, and eventually the mafia.  There is a healthy heaping of new music revolving around the 1% culture, weapons such as the sawn-off shotgun and grenade launcher, and mini-games in the clubhouse such as arm-wrestling and air hockey. One of the big improvements, at least in my eyes, is the use of mid-mission respawns. If you die or fail a mission, restarting it via phone will no longer pull you to the very beginning of the mission. You will probably respawn before the segment where you failed, started. This cuts down on the amount of needless driving when you fail a mission and makes it less of a hassle restarting.

The second episode is the Ballad of Gay Tony, which doesn't take you from the perspective of the flamboyantly gay Tony Prince (whom you may have noticed in Niko's story), but his bodyguard and partner Luis Lopez. If TLAD focused on motorcycles, it's safe to say that TBGT focused on helicopters, base jumping, parachuting, and night clubs. Again, TBGT's plot is interwoven into the original plot and fleshes out much of the why's and how's of that story. As with TLAD, there's almost a good half-dozen new mini-games, such as golf, dancing, drinking, parachuting, and races. If you had a hard time with the helicopter controls, then bad news, about 1/4 of the missions require piloting a helicopter at some point. Generally the storyline is well-written, the characters are great with Yusuf, the playboy millionaire Arab, Mori, the bodybuilding dwarf with a God complex, and Bulgarin, the Russian mobster collecting American rock memoribilia. The characters drive the storyline well and leaves the game with a satisfying conclusion.

Overall the game improves on a few issues from the original, but there are still a few things that hamper your gaming experience. Controls are still finicky, with driving still painful (you'll come to hate motorcycles on the final TBGT mission), flight controls difficult, and shooting still frustrating at times. It'll put a smile on your face when you see an NPC struggle to get in and out of a vehicle, but make you cringe when your characters' pathing causes him to dart back-and-forth around a vehicle. Mission restart has been improved, maybe some way of fast-travel would make driving less of a burden but I'm sure they want the playtime to be buffed higher by needless traveling. In summary, it's a strong buy and I highly recommend the game, I think that if you especially like the original then you'll find enjoyment with the episodes. 4.5/5.

reviewText:
It's GTA IV, but with more fluid game mechanics. What you probably want to hear is whether it's worth getting, whether it fills the gap until GTA 5 hits the shelves. So in a word, yes. In two words, sort of.

The game engine is still the GTA IV engine, of course; don't expect any dramatic changes between GTA IV and Episodes From Liberty City (EFLC). The only discernible differences are better driving (motorbikes! yay!) and cover taking mechanics, as well as slightly better AI and new radio content.

The graphics are still the same ones that taxed the hell outta all our PC's back when IV was released; this old engine seems to have been optimized quite a bit since then, even if the physics are still a bit buggy in large scale explosions or bridge traffic pileups (yup, they still periodically do that weird stacking thing on the bridge).

The AI as mentioned before has better cover taking, especially when in a firefight with allies. But, when ♥♥♥♥ gets real, you'll quickly realise that the AI can't handle certain things. There were moments in my playthrough where i'd be in a firefight and just move myself behind a solid object that i could still fire over or around, and find myself then being able to systematically slaughter any bot that had the temerity to walk into my fireline.

The soundtrack to the game is pretty decent. The LC Rock station with Iggy Pop in particular was to my mind the best thing about the Radio stations. There's a fair few gems in the limited new content the radio stations get, but after a while you'll probably find yourself adding your own music just to keep things fresh.

The storyline is alright; it fills in gaps between key events in Niko Bellic's story. In terms of the quality of the storytelling it's more or less your usual GTA fare. Lots of violence, swearing, racism, homophobia and misogyny coupled with explosions, gun fights and chase sequences. EFLC is just as cheesy, offensive and satirical as GTA has ever been, so if that's your bag you're in for a fun, nostalgic ride through that familiar virtual cesspit that is Liberty City.

To summarise, there's nothing really *new* here, and whilst it's certainly a lot of fun revisiting LC through the eyes of two very different characters, after the 30 or so hours of gameplay it takes to rinse through it all, you can't help but feel like it was fun, but you've done it all before. You'll almost certainly find yourself very quickly forgetting the characters and their stories, but at least you'll have enjoyed the process.

Overall: 3.5/5

Audio: 3/5
Graphics: 3/5

reviewText: Developers, take note. This is how you create DLC. Two episodes that span around 15 hours of gameplay (more if you're going to do everything). It feels like a whole new game. Yes, the city is still the same, but the stories aren't and the missions are quite diverse. One thing I really liked was the fact that all important characters are in a way part of the other characters' stories. reviewText: Grand Theft Auto: Episodes from Liberty City is a standalone compilation of the episodes for the 2008 video game Grand Theft Auto IV. reviewText:
While I hated GTA4, Episodes was actually WAY better.

The controls, driving, and some of the visuals are still crap, as well as the car limit and being infected with GFWL, but there were actually some improvements in a few areas.

Both extra campaigns each added some new and improved weapons, which added to the fun factor.

The Lost and Damned was focused around being a biker, and as a result made the game a lot more interesting. The choppers are some of the better handing vehicles in the game, and there was almost always at least one around, and so you never had to drive one of those 4 wheeled icy marshmellows commonly known as 'cars' in GTA4 unless you REALLY wanted to.

In addition to having your trusty gang deliver a bike to you whenever you wanted, you could also call them for backup, either just for fun, or to help you out on a difficult mission. Successfully completing missions leveled your gang members up, actually making them even more useful.

Lost was definitely the most enjoyable version of GTA4 for me. Probably because it felt a little more like Saints Row.

The Ballad of Gay Tony wasn't quite as good as Lost, mostly because you were back to reliance on cars for most of your traveling and didn't have the option of backup whenever you wanted. But it DID have the explosive shotgun.

And dancing. Don't ask me why the dancing was so fun. Maybe because the rest of the gameplay was so meh.

Getting a dance-off going at the Hercules was probably the best part of the episode.

Each episode was around 10 hours for mostly the story missions, but they felt a lot more fun overall. While you still got calls to hang out every so often, it wasn't nearly as bad as GTA4.

There also weren't as many difficult missions as there were in GTA4, and there were much more plentiful checkpoints in the ones that were difficult.

While Episodes still shares a lot of problems with GTA4, if you REALLY want to play a GTA4 game, I'd recommend just playing Episodes from Liberty City. There will be a few plot holes, but who's playing a GTA game for plot?

reviewText:
Bought this on sale for around £6 if memory serves. Just about the best value you could hope for. Two full length games in one. And GTA4 games at that.
Runs slightly better on my system than GTA4 too, which is a bonus. New radio stations are nice, new vehicles and weapons are excellent, and the new stories are very well written, acted and told.
As per usual you find it impossible to feel anything for the character you play, as they are both just scuzzy criminals with no morals and would kill their best friends for money, even though they keep going on about how important friends are.
Gay Tony is by far the best of the two, with an awesome new helicopter gunship, and a fantastic auto-shotgun with explosive ammo that smashes vehicles to peices with each shot. Hilarity obviously ensues when you do this to a police car.
I havent played MP yet, but it seems to be just the same thing as in GTA4, so if you liked that you will like this.
All in all a great game.
